File.Title: Topography of Descending Projections From the Inferior Colliculus to Auditory Brainstem Nuclei in the Rat

Abstract.S: We examined the organization of descending projections from the inferior colliculus (IC) to auditory brainstem nuclei and to pontine and reticular nuclei in the rat by employing the anterograde axonal tracer Phuseolus uulguris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L).
Small PHA-L injections into cytologically defined subnuclei of the IC revealed that each subnucleus has a unique pattern of efferent projections.

The central nucleus of the IC projects in a topographic order to the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus (DLL), the rostral periolivary nucleus (RPO), the ventral nucleus of the trapezoid body (VNTB), and the dorsal cochlear nucleus (DCN).
It is assumed that this topography represents a cochleotopic arrangement.
The external cortex of the IC projects to the nucleus sagulum (Sag), the RPO, the VNTB, and the DCN.
Minor projections were found to pontine and reticular nuclei.
Efferent fibers from the dorsal cortex of the IC terminate mainly in the Sag, while other nuclei of the auditory and extra-auditory brainstem receive only minor projections.
The intercollicular zone sends a moderate number of fibers to the DLL and very few, if any, to the remaining auditory brainstem nuclei.
In contrast, fairly strong projections from the intercollicular zone to the reticular formation were found.

Introduction.S: Auditory processing in the brainstem is performed by several medullary and mesencephalic nuclei that are connected with each other in a complex manner.
Acoustic signals are transmitted from the cochlea to the cochlear nuclei and then relayed through multiple parallel ascending pathways to higher auditory centers.
In turn, most of the higher centers have descending projections to lower auditory nuclei and even to the cochlea (for a recent review, see Huffman and Henson, '90).

Certain cell groups in the brainstem are exclusively concerned with descending pathways, while others, such as the inferior colliculus (IC), serve as relays for ascending, as well as descending, information.
Here we focus on descending projections of the IC to brainstem nuclei.

In the past, several studies of various mammalian species have appeared that have reported projections to auditory and extra-auditory nuclei in the brainstem, including the periolivarv and the cochlear nuclei (e.g., Rasmussen, '64; Moore and coldberg, '66; Noort, '69; Carey and Webster, '71; Borg, '73; Adams and Warr, '76; Kane and Conlee, '79; Andersen et al., '80; Conlee and Kane, '82; Hashikawa, '83; Syka et al., '881, the pontine nuclei (e.g., Aitkin and Boyd, '75; Kawamura, '75; Hashikawa, '83; Schuller et al., '911, and reticular nuclei (e.g., Andrezik et al., '81; Newman, '85).

However, despite the fairly large number of anatomical studies, only a few investigators have described a differential pattern of the projections from individual subnuclei of the IC to the auditory brainstem.
Studies dealing specifically with descending projections of the IC in the rat are scarce.

Faye-Lund ('86) showed collicular projections to the rostral periolivary nucleus, to the ventral nucleus of the trapezoid body, and to the dorsal cochlear nucleus all originating in the external cortex and in the central nucleus of the IC.

Recently, preliminary reports have suggested that in the rat, the projections from the central nucleus of the IC to the dorsal cochlear nucleus and the ventral nucleus of the trapezoid body are topographically organized (Saldana, '90, '911, and that the collicular fibers may contact neurons of the medial olivocochlear system (Vetter and Saldana, '90).

In the present investigation we analyzed the descending projections of four individual subnuclei of the IC in the rat, i.e., the central nucleus, the external and dorsal cortices, and the intercollicular zone, by using the anterograde axonal tracer Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L).

We were particularly interested in whether the anatomical and functional diversity of these IC subnuclei is also reflected in a differential pattern of descending pathways to auditory and extra-auditory brainstem nuclei and whether individual pathways exhibit a topographic order.
A preliminary report of this study has been previously published (Caicedo and Herbert, '91).

Methods.S: MATERIAL AND METHODS
The experiments were performed in 36 female SpragueDawley rats weighingZ10-320 g.
The animals were anesthetized with 7% chloral hydrate (40 mgi100 g body weight) and fixed in a stereotaxic device.
They received injections of the anterogradely transported axonal tracer PHA-L (2.5% in 10 mM sodium phosphate buffered saline, pH 8.0) into the different subnuclei of the IC.

The tracer was delivered iontophoretically through beveled glass micropipattes with 25-50 km tip diameters by means of a pulsed positive current of 5 p A with a 50% duty cycle (5 seconds onloff), which was applied for 15 minutes.
Tissue preparation

Six to 16 days after the PHA-L injections, the animals were anesthetized and perfused through the aorta with 0.9% saline, followed by the fixative prepared according to the two-step pH change protocol of Berod et al. ('81).
After perfusion with 200 ml of ice-cold 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 h4 sodium acetate buffer ipH 6.51, followed by 300 ml of ice-cold 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M borate buffer (pH l l .
O ) , the brains were removed and postfixed overnight at 4°C in the borate buffer fixative containing 56 sucrose.
The brains were then blocked and soaked for 2 days in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) containing 30% sucrose, at 4°C.
Tissue blocks from the lower medulla to the posterior thalamus were cut coronally on a freezing microtome at 40 km and divided into three series.
One series was further processed by the immunoperoxidasc technique.
The second series was mounted on gelatine-coated slides and stained for Nissl-substance with thionin; the third series was discarded.
Immunoperoxidase staining
Sections were immunohistochemically processed by the peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) method in order to identify PHA-L-labeled fibers.

First, the sections were rinsed in several changes of Tris-buffered saline (TBS) and then incubated in a blocking solution containing 10% normal goat serum, 2% bovine serum albumin (BSA), and 0.3%, Triton X-100 in 50 mM TBS, pH 7.6.

After 1 hour the sections were transferred into the primary antibody solution of rabbit anti-PHA-L (DAKO), diluted 1:3,000, in a carrier containing 1% normal goat serum, 1% BSA, and 0.3% Triton X-100 in TBS, and then incubated for 48 hours at 4°C.

Thereafter, the sections were rinsed for 30 minutes in several changes of TBS, transferred to an unlabeled swine anti-rabbit IgG antiserum (DAKO) diluted 150 in the carrier, and incubated for 1.5 hours at room temperature.
They were then extensively rinsed in TBS and incubated in a rabbit-PAP complex (DAKO) diluted 1: 150 in the carrier.
After 1.5 hours at room temperature, the sections were again rinsed in several changes of TBS.
The final visualization of the anterogradely transported PHA-L was accomplished by processing the sections in TBS, containing 0.05% 3,3-diaminobenzidine and 0.01% HzOz, for 5-15 minutes.
The incubation was stopped by transferring the sections into TBS.
After several rinses in TBS the sections were mounted on gelatine-coated slides, air dried, dehydrated in alcohol, cleared in xylene, and coverslipped with Entellan.
Data analysis
Of the 36 animals injected, the data of 22 animals, in which the injection sites were clearly confined to a single IC subnucleus, will be presented.
Sections were viewed by using brightfield illumination and Nomarski optics.
The location of the injection sites and the distribution of PHA-L-labeled fibers in the midbrain and medullary brainstem were mapped with a drawing tube.
The PHA-L injection sites in the IC appeared as homogeneous brown spots (Fig. 1) containing intensely labeled dark-brown somata (see Fig. 1C).
Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84) assumed that PHA-L is only incorporated into, and axonally transported from?
these labeled neurons.
We thus refer to the population of neurons that is filled by the tracer as the injection site.
Labeled axons were considered to represent terminal labeling when they were intensely arborized, had a curved and irregular course, and exhibited numerous en passant and terminal varicosities.
In contrast, traversing fibers generally had straight trajectories, larger diameters, and few, if any, axonal varicosities.

The location of labeled fibers within cytoarchitectural boundaries was defined by superimposing projections of the corresponding thionin-stained sections onto the drawings, with bran outlines and blood vessels as reference points.
Occasionally, we also observed retrogradely labeled somata resulting from the PHA-L injections into the IC, which is in accordance with the original report of Gerfen and Sawchenko ( 84).
The parcellation of the inferior colliculus is based on the studies of Faye-Lund and Osen ( 85) and Herbert et al
( 91) and those of the cochlear nucleus and the superior olivary complex are according to Osen et al. ( 84).
The parcellation of the lateral lemniscal nuclei and the adjacent areas is based on the cytoarchitecture in Nissl-stained sections of our material and is in accordance with PreuB 91).

Results.S: RESULTS

In order to analyze the descending projections of the inferior colliculus (IC), we placed small injections of the anterograde tracer PHA-L into individual subnuclei of the IC (Fig. 1) and mapped the distribution of presumed terminal fibers in the midbrain and brainstem.

We found that each IC subnucleus has a unique pattern of efferent projections, and furthermore, that the projections from the central nucleus of the IC to the auditory brainstem nuclei are topographically organized.
Injections into the central nucleus (ICC)

TTE.S: In 8 animals, PHA-L injections were confined to the ICC (e.g., Fig. 1A).

The PHA-L-labeled neurons in the injection site gave rise to a dense band of axonal labeling, oriented from ventrolateral to dorsomedial and extending from the central nucleus to layer 3 of the dorsal cortex of the IC (Fig. 1A).
Axonal labeling was also present in layer 3 of the external cortex of the IC.
In the contralateral IC a corresponding pattern of labeling was found, although less dense.

Results.S: Lateral lemniscal nuclei.
First, we will give a brief description of the parcellation of the lemniscal nuclei and the adjacent areas.
The dorsal nucleus ofthe lateral lemniscus (DLL) is clearly demonstrated in thionin-stained coronal sections as an oval nucleus made up of intensely stained, fairly large somata (Fig. 2).
The somata form dorsoventrally oriented cell columns which are aligned parallelly to the fascicles of the lateral lemniscus.
Ventrally, the DLL is bordered by a group of lightly stained, small cells whose flattened, fusiform somata are mediolaterally oriented (Fig. 2).
We have therefore termed it the horizontal cell group of the lateral lemniscus (H).
This horizontal cell group clearly separates the DLL from the further ventrally located intermediate nucleus of the lateral leniniscus (ILL).
The ILL consists of darkly stained, medium-sized neurons whose round to oval somata are also grouped in clusters formed by the lateral lemniscus (Fig. 2).
Medially, the nuclei of the lateral lemniscus are bordered by the perilemniscal zone (PI).
The lightly stained, small neurons of the PI appear like strings of pearls which are aligned along the dorsoventrally running fascicles of the lateral lemniscus (Fig. 2).
The nucleus saplum (Sag), finally, is situatedjust lateral to the DLL and can be identified by its lighterstained, medium-sized somata (Fig. 2).
Efferent fibers could be traced leaving the ICC in its ventralmost part and entering the lateral lemniscus where they ran ventrally without having a preferential location within the tract.

At the level of the ipsilateral DLL, numerous fibers gave off axond collaterals, which then entered the DLL (Fig. 3C,D), thereby forming two medidat.erally oriented bands of terminal labeling (Fig. 4).
Highpower light microscopy revealed that the terminal fibers in the DLL were intensely beaded.
They were often found closely apposed to horizontally oriented neuronal somata and primary dendrites (Fig. 3A-F), presumably forming synaptic contacts.
Occasionally, terminal axons were located in close proximity to retrogradely labeled neurons (Figs. 3A,F, 4C), indicating a reciprocity of the ICC/DLLconnections.

The intermediate nucleus of the lateral lemniscus received only a sparse projection from the ICC, while the ventral nucleus, as well as all contralateral nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, were devoid of fibers.

TTE.S: A shift of injection sites along the dorsoventral axis of the ICC resulted in a change in the position of the terminal labeling within the DLL.
After injections into the dorsal part of the ICC were made, two horizontally oriented bands of axonal labeling appeared in the middle portion of the DLL (Fig. 5, experiment IC 41).
Injections placed into medial aspects of the ICC also resulted in two labeled bands.
However, each band had shifted vertically towards the dorsal and ventral periphery (Fig. 5, experiment IC 33).
Finally, in the case of ventral ICC injections, the labeling was seen to have reached the dorsal and ventral boundaries of the DLL (Fig. 5, experiment IC 31; see also Fig. 4A,B).
Superior oliuary complex.

Numerous labeled fibers in the lateral lemniscus could also be seen running further ventrally, then entering the rostrd periolivary region (RPO) and the ventral nucleus of the trapezoid body (VNTB; Fig. 6A-C).
Within the ipsilateral RPO and VNTB the fibers arborized intensely and formed a dense axonal plexus which exhibited numerous en passant and terminal varicosities (Fig. 6D,E).
In the VNTB, labeled axons were often seen closely apposed to large VNTB neurons (Fig. 6D).
In addition, very sparse axonal labeling was found in the superior paraolivary nucleus and in the dorsal periolivary region (Fig. 7).
Injections into dorsal, versus ventral, parts of the ICC also resulted in a shift of the anterograde labeling in the RPO and the VNTB.

PHA-L injections placed dorsally in the ICC gave rise to terminal labeling in lateral aspects of the RPO and VNTB (Fig. 7, experiment JC 421, while, after injecting middle parts of the ICC, terminal labeling occupied middle aspects of the RPO and VNTB (Fig. 7, experiment IC 33).
Finally, injections into the ventral part of the ICC resulted in terminal labeling in the most medial aspects of the RPO and VNTB (Fig. 3, experiment IC 46; see also Fig. 6A-C).
In each experiment the axonal labeling in the RPO and the VNTB appeared as a continuous column stretching throughout the entire rostrocaudal extent of the nuclei (e.g., Fig. 7A-D).
Corresponding to the dorsoventral shift of the injection sites in the ICC, this continuous column of labeled fibers moved from lateral to medial in the RPO and VNTB (Fig. 7).
Cochlear nucleus.
Labeled fibers also coursed through the trapezoid body and through the dorsal acoustic stria, where they ran bilaterally towards the dorsal cochlear nuclei (DCN).
Within the DCN the presumed terminal fibers branched extensively and exhibited numerous en passant and terminal varicosities (Figs. 8, 9).
The fibers formed a narrow band oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the DCN (Fig. 8Cj.

This band of fibers extended from the deep layer of the DCN into the fusiform cell layer without entering the outermost molecular layer (Fig. 9B,Di, and it continued along the rostrocaudal extent of the DCN (Fig. 10).
Some labeled fibers were also found in the granule cell areas which surround the ventral cochlear nucleus (Fig. 10).
Beaded axons were often found in close proximity to neuronal somata in the contralateral DCN, presumably forming synaptic contacts (Figs.
SA, 9D).
Occasiondly, labeled axons were also seen closely apposed to retrogradely labeled somata, indicating reciprocity of the crossed ICCi DCN-connections (Fig.
SB!.
Our experiments further revealed that the projection from the ICC to the DCN is also topographically organized.

After small PHA-L injections into the dorsal ICC we observed a narrow band of terminal labeling in the ventrolateral part of the DCN, which was oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the nucleus (Fig. 10, experiment IC 42).
The labeling within the DCN shifted dorsomedially when PHA-L injections were placed further ventrally into the ICC (Fig. 10, experiment TC 33).
After the tracer was deposited most ventrally in the ICC, the terminal fibers were found in the dorsomedial aspect of the DCN (Fig. 10, experiment IC 46; see also Fig. 9).

In addition to labeled fibers in the auditory nuclei, presumed terminal fibers were present ipsilaterally in nuclei of the reticular formation, which are not considered a part of the auditory pathway proper.
These reticular nuclei included the pontine nucleus and the lateral paragigantocellular nucleus (Fig. 12).

Results.S: Injections into the external cortex (EC)

TTE.S: Five animals received PHA-L injections centered in the EC (e.g., Fig. 1D).
These injections resulted in considerable anterograde labeling bilaterally in the EC and DC, both with an ipsilateral predominance.
In contrast, the ICC was largely devoid of labeled fibers.
Efferent axons emerging from the EC ran ventrally into the lateral lemniscus.
Along their course, fibers emitted varicose axonal branches into the nucleus sagulum and the horizontal cell group (Fig. 11, experiment IC 26).
The core nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, i.e., the dorsal, intermediate, and ventral nuclei, were largely devoid of fibers.
Labeled axons also ran further ventrally through the lateral lemniscus, entering the superior olivary complex.
There they formed a dense plexus of presumed terminal fibers within the ipsilateral RPO and VNTB (Fig. 12).
In contrast to the efferents from the ICC, the terminating axons from the EC did not show a topographical arrangement, but were evenly distributed in the RPO and VNTB.
Individual labeled fibers were also present in the superior paraolivary nucleus and in the dorsal and caudal periolivary region.
Labeled fibers were further found bilaterally in the trapezoid body and in the dorsal acoustic stria, running towards both cochlear nuclei.
There the labeled axons arborized and formed diffuse patches of presumed terminal fibers bilaterally in the DCN and in the granule cell layers (Fig. 12).

Prominent anterograde axonal labeling was also present ipsilaterally in various nuclei of the reticular formation. including the pontine nucleus, the ventrolateral tegmental nucleus, the gigantocellular reticular nucleus, and the lateral paragigantocellular nucleus (Fig. 12).

Results.S: Injections into the dorsal cortex (DC)

TTE.S: In four animals the PHA-L injections were confined to the DC.
In these cases, intranuclear labeling was seen bilaterally in layers 2 and 3 of the DC, with an ipsilateral predominance.
In the ipsilateral EC, patches of anterogradely labeled fibers were found in layer 2.
Remarkable was the absence of terminal labeling in the ICC, where only traversing axons could be observed.
Descending fibers leaving the IC entered the lateral lemniscus, where some of them branched to form a prominent plexus of varicose fibers in the nucleus sagulum (Fig. 11, experiment IC 45).
The core nuclei of the lateral lemniscus were largely devoid of terminal fibers.
In the superior olivary complex there was only sparse labeling in the RPO and the VNTB.
Also, in the DCN the anterograde labeling was very scarce compared to the labeling after injections into the ICC or the EC.

It should be noted that the efferent projections from the DC to lower auditory brainstem nuclei were far more limited compared to those from the ICC and the EC, and that the major target area of DC fibers appears to be the nucleus sagulum (Fig. 12).
Projections from the DC to the reticular formation were restricted to the lateral paragigantocellular nucleus (Fig. 12).

Results.S: Injections into the intercollicular zone (IZ)

TTE.S: In six animals PHA-L injections were placed into the IZ (corresponding in location to the rostra1 portion of the EC, as defined by Faye-Lund and Osen, '85).
These injections resulted in extensive axonal labeling in the ipsilateral EC, extending into its most caudal pole.
In the remaining IC subnuclei, only sparse labeling was present.
Descending axons from the IZ could be traced entering the lateral lemniscus, where they branched and formed a dense plexus of varicose fibers within the confines of the ipsilateral DLL.
Only few labeled fibers were found in the horizontal cell group and the perilemniscal zone.
In the remaining nuclei of the lower auditory brainstem only sparse terminal labeling was observed.
A remarkable feature of the projections from the IZ is the prominent input to pontine and medullary reticular nuclei.

Presumed terminal fibers were seen ipsilaterally in the ventrolateral tegmental nucleus and in the lateral paragigantocellular nucleus, as well as bilaterally in the caudal and oral pontine reticular nuclei and in the gigantocellular reticular nucleus (Fig. 12).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
The present study has demonstrated that the subnuclei of the IC have a differential pattern of descending projections (summarized in Fig. 12).

The collicular projections to lower auditory nuclei originate primarily in the central nucleus and the external cortex, while the dorsal cortex and the intercollicular zone have only modest descending projections.

Furthermore, we found that the efferent projections from the central nucleus to the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, the rostral periolivary nucleus, the ventral nucleus of the trapezoid body, and the dorsal cochlear nuclei are topographically organized.
Each subnucleus of the IC also projects, more or less prominently, to various extra-auditory nuclei of the pons and the reticular formation.
Colliculolemniscal projections

Our tracing experiments revealed that the collicular projections to the lateral lemniscus are largely confined to the dorsal nucleus, the sagulum, the horizontal cell group, and the perilemniscal zone.
The rat's intermediate and ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus receives few, if any, collicular fibers, which is in line with the findings of Faye-Lund ('86).

However, this contrasting result could be due to species differences or, as assumed by Faye-Lund, actually represents a projection to the rostra1 periolivary nucleus, Projections to the dorsal nucleus.
Injections of PHA-L into the central nucleus of the IC yielded two distinct horizontal bands of presumed terminal labeling in the ipsilateral DLL.

We report for the first time that this projection is topographically arranged: neurons located dorsally in the central nucleus (corresponding to a lowfrequency site, Clopton and Winfield, '73) project to the middle portion of the DLL; neurons located ventrally in the central nucleus (corresponding to a high-frequency site) project to the peripheral, i.e., the dorsal and ventral aspect of the DLL.
Because of the clear-cut separation of the DLL and the ILL by the horizontal cell group, we can rule out that the ventral band of labeling might actually be located in the dorsal aspect of the ILL.

Other studies which reported colliculolemniscal connections in various species also pointed to the DLL as the major target nucleus, but did not demonstrate a topographic order (Moore and Goldberg, '66; Carey and Webster, '71; Borg, '73; Andersen et al., '80; Syka et al., 88).
In addition, the DLL receives a diffuse input from the intercollicular zone, and yet receives hardly any fibers from the external and dorsal cortices of the IC.

The horizontal lamination of labeled collicular axons in the DLL, as reported in the present study, is in agreement with morphological and anatomical descriptions of the DLL in the rat, mouse, and cat.
In Golgi-stained material, DLI, neurons and terminal fibers within the DLL appear to be oriented horizontally (Kane and Barone, 80; Morest and Oliver, 84; Iwahori, 86).
Iwahori ( 86) further reported that axons in the DLL form horizontally oriented pericellular baskets, which closely track the somadendritic shape of DLL neurons.

Similar observations were made of colliculolemniscal axons (present study, see Fig. 3E), as well as of GAl3Aimmunoreactive varicosities, which are aligned horizontally along the soma and dendrites of DLL neurons (Adams and Mugnaini, 84; Moore and Moore; 87).

Furthermore, terminal fibers ascending from auditory nuclei of the brainstem are also found in horizontal laminae in the DLL, as are the neurons of the DLL, which project to the IC (Henkel and Spangler, 83; Shneiderman et al., 85; PreuI3, 91).
The lamination in the DLL may provide the morphological substrate for a cochleotopic frequency representation within the DLL.
Recent studies in our laboratory provided first evidence of a tonotopic organization of the rat s DLL.

The frequency representation was demonstrated by a c-fos study after pure-tone acoustic stimulation: high-frequency neurons were found to be located ventrally and dorsally in the DLL, while low-frequency neurons were found centrally in the DLL (see Fig. 1E in Friauf, 92).

These findings are corroborated by results based on injections of two retrograde fluorescent tracers into electrophysiologically characterized sites in the central nucleus of the IC, which showed the same mirror-symmetric arrangement of labeled neurons in the DLL (PreuJ3, 91).
These facts support our assumption that the topography of the colliculolemniscal projection has a cochleotopic organization.

Our data on the tonotopic organization of the rat s DLL are, however, apparently in contrast to physiological (Aitkin et al., 70) and anatomical findings in the cat s DLL (Shneiderman et al., 88), which showed that the high-to-low frequency axis is oriented from ventral to dorsal.

The DLL is primarily considered to be a relay in the ascending auditory pathway, projecting bilaterally, in a cochleotopic fashion, to the central nucleus of the IC (Shneiderman et al., '88; PreuB, '91).
As many neurons in the DLL are GABAergic, they may provide an inhibitory input to IC neurons (Adams and Mugnaini, '84; Moore and Moore, '87; Shneiderman et al., '88).
Taken together, it is possible that the colliculolemniscal projection modulates this presumed inhibitory ascending input, thus forming a short frequency-specific feedback loop.
Projections to the perilemniscal areas.
The present study revealed that the sagulum, the horizontal cell group, and the perilemniscal zone receive efferent collicular fibers from the ipsilateral external and dorsal cortex of the IC only.
A projection from the external cortex to the sagulum has already been reported in the rat (Faye-Lund; '86) arid also in the monkey (Moore and Goldberg, '66).

This collicular pathway could mediate information from the auditory cortex to the sagulum, since both the external and dorsal cortex are major recipients of auditory cortical projections (Faye-Lund, '85; Herbert et al., '91 j.

In the rat and cat, the sagulum projects to the dorsal and external cortex of the IC (PreuB, '91; Henkel and Shneiderman, '88) and thus appears to be reciprocally connected with the respective IC subnuclei.

The sagulum, which is considered a part of the lateral tegmental system (Morest, '65; Morest and Oliver, '84; Henkel and Shneiderman, '88), is also the origin of a direct projection to the medial and dorsal nucleus of the medial geniculate body (Oliver and Hall, '781, thus providing a parallel ascending projection to the auditory thalamus.
Presumably, the collicular projections to the saylum provide an auditory input to this component of the lateral tegmental system.
Colliculoolivary projections
Our data demonstrate that the ipsilateral rostral periolivary nucleus (RPO) and the ventral nucleus of the trapezoid body (VNTB) are the primary targets of colliculoolivary projections.

This is in general agreement with previous findings in mammals (Moore and Goldberg, '66; Noort, '69; Carey and Webster, '71; Borg, '73; Andersen et al., '80; Conlee and Kane, '82; Hashikawa, '83; Syka et al., '88).

Our results, showing that both the external cortex and the central nucleus of the IC give rise to this projection, extend the findings of Faye-Lund ('86) and support two recent conference notes (Saldafia, '90; Vetter and Saldafia, '90).
The intercollicular zone and the dorsal cortex of the IC send only a few, if any, fibers to the superior olivary complex.
Projections to the RPO and the VNTB.

PHA-L injections into the external cortex and the central nucleus of the IC resulted in dense axonal labeling ipsilaterally in ventral aspects of the RPO and VNTB, thereby forming a continuous band which extends from the rostral tip of the RPO to the caudal portion of the VNTB.
This was also observed by Faye-Lund ('861, using anterograde degeneration.
The colliculofugal terminal fibers in this area appear to overlap the site of origin of the medial olivocochlear bundle (White and Warr, '83).

In the rat, this system contains cholinergic neurons (White and Warr, '83; Osen et al., '84; Faye-Lund, '86; Vetter et al., '91) which are located exclusively in the RPO and VNTB and innervate the outer hair cells of the contralateral cochlea (Iurato, '74; White and Warr, '83; Aschoff and Ostwald, '88).

Evidence of a termination of collicular fibers on these olivocochlear neurons was provided by a tracing study in which PHA-L-labeled fibers from the IC were found in close apposition to retrogradely labeled neurons of the medial olivocochlear system (Vetter and Saldaiia, '90).
However, whether these fibers indeed form synaptic contacts requires verification by electron microscopy.
The anatomical data already indicate that the colliculoolivary pathway may participate in the modulation of cochlear responses.

Functional evidence has been provided by physiological studies in which electrical stimulation of the IC reduced temporary threshold shift after intensive exposure to noise, thus protecting the cochlea from auditory desensitization (Rajan, '90).
Furthermore, electrical stimulation of the IC produces a reduction in the amplitude and an increase in the latency of the auditory whole-nerve response (Dolan and Nutall, '88).

As these effects are similar to those elicited by electrical stimulation of the crossed olivocochlear system (reviewed in Rajan, '901, it is conceivable that the IC influences the cochlear responses via the medial olivocochlear system, A major finding of our study is that fibers from the central nucleus of the IC terminate in a highly organized fashion within the RPO and VNTB.
Neurons located dorsally in the central nucleus project to the lateral parts of RPO and VNTB, while neurons located ventrally project to the medial parts.
A topographic organization of this pathway has been recently noted by Saldaiia ('90) as well.

It appears that the shift of terminal collicular fibers follows the cochleotopic organization of the RPO-VNTB complex, with a low-to-high frequency representation from lateral to medial, as was demonstrated in the rat by means of the c-fos technique (Friauf, '92).
Neurons of the medial olivocochlear system in the guinea pig exhibit a similar cochleotopic arrangement and apparently project tonotopically to the outer hair cells (Robertson and Gummer, '88).

In conclusion, the data indicate that the colliculo-olivocochlear pathway, originating in the central nucleus, is entirely cochleotopically organized and thus, may modulate cochlear responses frequency-specifically.
The external cortex of the IC also provides input to the RPO and VNTB, although in a diffuse manner.

The fact that the external cortex receives direct auditory cortical (Faye-Lund, '85; Herbert et al., '911, as well as somatosensory input (Aitkin et al., %I), suggests that its colliculoolivary fibers may transmit multimodal information and thus represent a descending pathway which is functionally separate from the pathway originating in the ICC.
Projections to the cochlear nuclei
We found that the DCN is a major target of collicular projections originating in the external cortex and the central nucleus.
While few collicular fibers were found in the granule cell layers surrounding the ventral cochlear nuclei, the ventral cochlear nuclei proper were completely devoid of fibers.
The existence of a collicular input to the cochlear nuclei was already reported in the past century for cats, rats, rabbits, and humans (Held, 1893).
Since then, various degeneration and tracing studies have confirmed this pathway in different mammalian species (Rasmussen, '64; Noort, '69; Adams and Warr, '76; Kane and Conlee!
'79; Lorente de NO, '81; Hashikawa, '83; Faye-Lund, '86; Shore et al., '91).

In the cat, the projection from the IC to the DCN was reported to be complementary, i.e., superficial collicular structures project to the outermost layers of the DCN, whereas deep collicular structures (corresponding to the central nucleus) project to the deep layers of the DCN (Conlee and Kane, '82).
By means of the sensitive axonal tracer PHA-L we could demonstrate that the organization of this pathway in the rat is differently arranged.
Projections to the dorsal cochlear nucleus.
Collicular fibers reach the cochlear nucleus via the ventral and the dorsal acoustic stria and terminatp bilaterally at homotopic sites in the deep layers of the DCN.

Fibers originating in the central nucleus terminate in a topographic fashion, thereby forming discrete bands which are oriented perpendicular to the surface of the nucleus, a finding that is in line with a Sag Gi LPGi PnC VLTg Pn
recent note (Saldana, '91).
This preferred orientation matches the overall axonal and dendritic arrangement within the DCN.

The dendrites of pyramidal and vertical cells and the recurrent axonal collaterals of cartwheel cells are aligned along isofrequency bands, which are created by the type I primary cochlear nerve fibers (Blackstad et al., '84; Berrebi and Mugnaini, '91).
Physiological studies have shown that low frequencies are represented ventrolaterally and high frequencies dorsomedially in the rat's DCN (Ryan et al., '88; Friauf, '92).
Thus, the fibers from the central nucleus appear to terminate according to the cochleotopic frequency arrangement in the DCN.
We are not aware of any study in which the physiological significance of the projections from the central nucleus of the IC to the DCN has been investigated.

Since the DCN provides a prominent, cochleotopically organized input to the contralateral central nucleus of the IC (Beyerl, '78), it is possible that these nuclei are reciprocally connected through frequency-specific channels.
Projections to the granule cell layers.

After PHA-L injections were made into both the central nucleus or the external cortex of the IC, we always found, without any apparent order, terminal labeling in the granule cell layers of the cochlear nucleus.
This is consistent with the fact that axons of granule cells traverse isofrequency layers in the DCN (Mugnaini et al., '80).

The granule cells receive multiple afferents, including somatosensory inputs, and project to the molecular layer of the DCN, forming synaptic contacts with interneurons (cartwheel cells) and pyramidal cells (for review, see Osen, '88).
Granule cells thus modulate DCN interneurons, as well as neurons projecting to the central nucleus of the IC.
Projections to pontine and mesencephalic reticular nuclei

In addition to projections to lower auditory brainstem nuclei, we found that the subnuclei of the IC also contribute differentially to projections into pontine and mesencephalic reticular nuclei (summarized in Fig. 12).

Collicular pathways leading to some of these extra-auditory nuclei have been previously reported (pontine nuclei: Moore and Goldberg, '66; Carey and Webster, '71; Aitkin and Boyd, '75; Kawamura, '75; Mower et al., '79; Andersen et al., '80; Schweizer, '81; Hashikawa, '83; Schuller et al., '91; lateral paragigantocellular nucleus: Andrezik et al., '81; Newman, '85).
In addition, we found collicular fibers in the gigantocellular reticular nucleus, the ventrolateral tegmental nucleus, and in the caudal pontine reticular nucleus.
Recently we were able to demonstrate that these same pontine and reticular nuclei also receive a prominent auditory input from the cochlear nuclei (Kandler and Herbert, '91).

It is conceivable that auditory projections to these extraauditory areas may play a role in longand short-latency audio-motor behaviors or in acoustically elicited autonomic responses (for an extensive discussion on the functional significance of auditory projections to pontine and reticular nuclei we refer to Kandler and Herbert, '91).
